key_points: A ship operated by Evergreen Marine Corp., the same company behind the Suez Canal blockage, accidentally spilled 28,800 plastic toys into the Pacific Ocean in the 1990s.
The plastic toys consisted of 7,200 red beavers, 7,200 green frogs, 7,200 blue turtles, and 7,200 yellow ducks.
The incident's details are covered in Donovan Hohn's 2011 book, "Moby-Duck: The True Story of 28,800 Bath Toys Lost at Sea."
The spill was eventually linked to the Ever Laurel, operated by Evergreen Marine, which left Hong Kong on January 6, 1992, and arrived in Tacoma, Washington, on January 16, 1992.
Oceanographers Jim Ingraham and Curtis Ebbesmeyer used a ocean-current surface simulator to trace the plastic toys' drift patterns back to the North Pacific.
The toys were still being found on shores around the world 15 years later, with the most recent sighting in the UK in 2007.
Evergreen Marine recently made headlines again due to the Ever Given, a container ship that blocked the Suez Canal, causing significant economic impact.
The blockage of the Suez Canal by the Ever Given is estimated to have cost the global economy $400 million per hour.
Shoei Kisen, the owner of the Ever Given, expressed apologies for the disruption and aimed to free the vessel on Saturday.
The connection between the two incidents highlights the ongoing challenges and unintended consequences of global shipping operations.
